mn122:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.
mn122:2.1: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Kapilavatthu for alms.
mn122:2.2: He wandered for alms in Kapilavatthu. After the meal, on his return from almsround, he went to the lodge of the Sakyan Khemaka the Dark for the day’s meditation.
mn122:2.3: Now at that time many resting places had been spread out at the lodge of Khemaka the Dark.
mn122:2.6: “Many resting places have been spread out;
mn122:2.7: are there many mendicants living here?”
mn122:2.8: Now at that time Venerable Ānanda, together with many other mendicants, was making robes at the lodge of the Sakyan Ghaṭā.
mn122:2.9: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to Ghaṭā’s lodge, where he sat on the seat spread out
mn122:2.11: “Many resting places have been spread out at the lodge of Khemaka the Dark;
mn122:2.15: It’s currently the time for making robes.”
mn122:3.1: “Ānanda, a mendicant doesn’t shine who enjoys company and groups, who loves them and likes to enjoy them.
mn122:3.2: It is quite impossible that such a mendicant will get the pleasure of renunciation, the pleasure of seclusion, the pleasure of peace, the pleasure of awakening when they want, without trouble or difficulty.
mn122:3.3: But you should expect that a mendicant who lives alone, withdrawn from the group, will get the pleasure of renunciation, the pleasure of seclusion, the pleasure of peace, the pleasure of awakening when they want, without trouble or difficulty. That is possible.
mn122:4.1: Indeed, Ānanda, it is quite impossible that a mendicant who enjoys company will enter and remain in the freedom of heart—either that which is temporary and pleasant, or that which is irreversible and unshakable.
mn122:4.2: But it is possible that a mendicant who lives alone, withdrawn from the group will enter and remain in the freedom of heart—either that which is temporary and pleasant, or that which is irreversible and unshakable.
mn122:5.1: Ānanda, I do not see even a single sight which, with its decay and perishing, would not give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress in someone who has desire and lust for it.
mn122:6.1: But this meditation has been understood by the Realized One, namely
mn122:6.2: to enter and remain in emptiness internally by not focusing on any signs.
mn122:6.3: Now, suppose that while the Realized One is practicing this meditation, monks, nuns, laymen, laywomen, rulers and their chief ministers, monastics of other religions and their disciples go to visit him.
mn122:6.4: In that case, with a mind slanting, sloping, and inclining to seclusion, withdrawn, and loving renunciation, having totally eliminated defiling influences, he invariably gives a talk concerned only with sending them away.

mn122:8.5: That’s how a mendicant stills, settles, unifies, and immerses their mind in samādhi internally.

mn122:11.1: While a mendicant is practicing such a meditation, if their mind inclines to walking, they walk, thinking:
mn122:11.2: ‘While I’m walking, bad, unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure will not overwhelm me.’
mn122:11.3: In this way they are aware of the situation.
mn122:11.4: While a mendicant is practicing such a meditation, if their mind inclines to standing, they stand, thinking:
mn122:11.5: ‘While I’m standing, bad, unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure will not overwhelm me.’
mn122:11.6: In this way they are aware of the situation.
mn122:11.7: While a mendicant is practicing such a meditation, if their mind inclines to sitting, they sit, thinking:
mn122:11.8: ‘While I’m sitting, bad, unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure will not overwhelm me.’
mn122:11.9: In this way they are aware of the situation.
mn122:11.10: While a mendicant is practicing such a meditation, if their mind inclines to lying down, they lie down, thinking:
mn122:11.11: ‘While I’m lying down, bad, unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure will not overwhelm me.’
mn122:11.12: In this way they are aware of the situation.
mn122:12.1: While a mendicant is practicing such a meditation, if their mind inclines to talking, they think:
mn122:12.2: ‘I will not engage in the kind of speech that is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. Such speech doesn’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. Namely: talk about kings, bandits, and chief ministers; talk about armies, threats, and wars; talk about food, drink, clothes, and beds; talk about garlands and fragrances; talk about family, vehicles, villages, towns, cities, and countries; talk about women and heroes; street talk and well talk; talk about the departed; motley talk; tales of land and sea; and talk about being reborn in this or that state of existence.’
mn122:12.3: In this way they are aware of the situation.
mn122:12.4: ‘But I will take part in talk about self-effacement that helps open the heart and leads solely to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. That is, talk about fewness of wishes, contentment, seclusion, aloofness, arousing energy, ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and the knowledge and vision of freedom.’
mn122:12.5: In this way they are aware of the situation.
mn122:13.1: While a mendicant is practicing such a meditation, if their mind inclines to thinking, they think:
mn122:13.2: ‘I will not think the kind of thought that is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. Such thoughts don’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. That is, sensual, malicious, or cruel thoughts.’
mn122:13.3: In this way they are aware of the situation.
mn122:13.4: ‘But I will think the kind of thought that is noble and emancipating, and brings one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering. That is, thoughts of renunciation, good will, and harmlessness.’
mn122:13.5: In this way they are aware of the situation.

mn122:18.1: These principles are entirely skillful, with skillful outcomes; they are noble, transcendent, and inaccessible to the Wicked One.
mn122:19.2: For what reason would a disciple deem it worthwhile to follow the Teacher, even if driven away?”
mn122:19.3: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. He is our guide and our refuge. Sir, may the Buddha himself please clarify the meaning of this. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
mn122:20.1: “A disciple would not deem it worthwhile to follow the Teacher for the sake of this, namely statements, mixed prose & verse, or discussions.
mn122:20.3: Because for a long time you have learned the teachings, remembering them, rehearsing them, mentally scrutinizing them, and penetrating them theoretically.
mn122:20.4: But a disciple would deem it worthwhile to follow the Teacher, even if driven away, for the sake of talk about self-effacement that helps open the heart and leads solely to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. That is, talk about fewness of wishes, contentment, seclusion, aloofness, arousing energy, ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and the knowledge and vision of freedom.
mn122:21.1: This being so, Ānanda, there is a peril for the tutor, a peril for the pupil, and a peril for a spiritual practitioner.
mn122:22.1: And how is there a peril for the tutor?
mn122:22.2: It’s when some teacher frequents a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
mn122:22.3: While meditating withdrawn, they’re visited by a stream of brahmins and householders, and people of town and country.
mn122:22.4: When this happens, they enjoy infatuation, fall into greed, and return to indulgence.
mn122:22.5: This is said to be the tutor’s peril.
mn122:22.6: They’re ruined by bad, unskillful qualities that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death.
mn122:22.7: That’s how there is a peril for the tutor.
mn122:23.1: And how is there a peril for the pupil?
mn122:23.2: It’s when the disciple of a teacher, emulating their teacher’s fostering of seclusion,
mn122:23.3: frequents a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
mn122:23.4: While meditating withdrawn, they’re visited by a stream of brahmins and householders, and people of town and country.
mn122:23.5: When this happens, they enjoy infatuation, fall into greed, and return to indulgence.
mn122:23.6: This is said to be the pupil’s peril.
mn122:23.7: They’re ruined by bad, unskillful qualities that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death.
mn122:23.8: That’s how there is a peril for the pupil.
mn122:24.1: And how is there a peril for a spiritual practitioner?
mn122:24.2: It’s when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.
mn122:24.3: He frequents a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
mn122:24.4: While meditating withdrawn, he’s visited by a stream of brahmins and householders, and people of town and country.
mn122:24.5: When this happens, he doesn’t enjoy infatuation, fall into greed, and return to indulgence.
mn122:24.6: But a disciple of this teacher, emulating their teacher’s fostering of seclusion,
mn122:24.7: frequents a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
mn122:24.8: While meditating withdrawn, they’re visited by a stream of brahmins and householders, and people of town and country.
mn122:24.9: When this happens, they enjoy infatuation, fall into greed, and return to indulgence.
mn122:24.10: This is said to be the spiritual practitioner’s peril.
mn122:24.11: They’re ruined by bad, unskillful qualities that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death.
mn122:24.12: That’s how there is a peril for the spiritual practitioner.
mn122:24.13: And in this context, Ānanda, as compared to the peril of the tutor or the pupil, the peril of the spiritual practitioner has more painful, bitter results, and even leads to the underworld.
mn122:25.1: So, Ānanda, treat me as a friend, not as an enemy.
mn122:25.2: That will be for your lasting welfare and happiness.
mn122:25.3: And how do disciples treat their Teacher as an enemy, not a friend?
mn122:25.4: It’s when the Teacher teaches Dhamma to his disciples out of kindness and sympathy:
mn122:25.5: ‘This is for your welfare. This is for your happiness.’
mn122:25.6: But their disciples don’t want to listen. They don’t actively listen or try to understand. They proceed having turned away from the Teacher’s instruction.
mn122:25.7: That’s how the disciples treat their Teacher as an enemy, not a friend.
mn122:26.1: And how do disciples treat their Teacher as a friend, not an enemy?
mn122:26.2: It’s when the Teacher teaches Dhamma to his disciples out of kindness and sympathy:
mn122:26.3: ‘This is for your welfare. This is for your happiness.’
mn122:26.4: And their disciples want to listen. They actively listen and try to understand. They don’t proceed having turned away from the Teacher’s instruction.
mn122:26.5: That’s how the disciples treat their Teacher as a friend, not an enemy.
mn122:26.6: So, Ānanda, treat me as a friend, not as an enemy.
mn122:26.7: That will be for your lasting welfare and happiness.
mn122:27.1: I shall not mollycoddle you like a potter with their damp, unfired pots.
mn122:27.2: I shall speak, correcting you again and again,
mn122:27.4: The core will stand the test.”
mn122:27.5: That is what the Buddha said.
mn122:27.6: Satisfied, Venerable Ānanda approved what the Buddha said.
